summary: all materials moved from a higher level of biocontainment to a lower biocontainment level must be proven to be sterile or undergo a valid and verified method of agent inactivation. this involves inoculating a portion of the material or biological agent containing the sample to be moved to a medium capable of supporting growth of the target organism. the media and assays used to detect viable organisms will vary depending on the target agents. inactivation procedure may be moved to a lower biocontainment level, transported, and disposed of without a sterility test. the material subjected to the process is considered sterile. sterility tests are not performed on every sample that undergoes autoclaving as a method of disposal. the toxicity of the TRIzol LS in undiluted, treated viral samples causes almost immediate death of the cell culture layer used for sterility testing. previous studies have diluted the TRIzol LS-inactivated samples 100- and 1000-fold and still observed tissue culture cell death. the photo-crosslinking property of psoralens has been exploited to inactivate microorganisms in the blood supply [13,14,15] for the treatment of skin disorders [16], to inactivate viral pathogens prior to organ transplantation, and for inactivation of viruses for potential vaccines [17,18,19,20]. Flow cytometry was used to establish that viruses inactivated with AMT were still competent to interact with DC-SIGN cellular receptors and become internalized. psoralen-inactivated DENV was captured and internalized to the same extent as live DENV in host cells. method of inactivating virus preparations was extended to multiple virus families. the method was effective at inactivating Alpha-, Arena-, Bunya-, Corona-, Filo-, Flavi- and orthomyxoviruses. each virus tested required a different amount of UV-A exposure in the presence of AMT. the polyclonal antibodies produced against inactivated virus worked equally well for detecting untreated virus compared to antibodies produced against live virus preparations. this will allow viruses inactivated by this method to be used in vaccine development, in antibody generation for research, or studied by microscopy. the viral nucleic acids were non-infectious and sufficiently undamaged in DENV to be appropriate substrates for real time PCR. the UV-A exposure time and AMT concentration required to inactivate each virus is affected by viral titer and is species-specific. this method could provide rapid access to virus preparations and genomic material from pathogenic samples quickly and safely.
